title: Projects
text:
Predicting House Prices with Machine Learning



Python

Machine Learning

Data Cleaning



This project involves using machine learning algorithms to predict house prices based on various features such as location, size, and amenities. It includes data cleaning, feature engineering, and model selection.



Jan 1, 2024













Customer Segmentation Using Clustering Techniques



R

Machine Learning

Clustering

Statistical Modelling



This project focuses on segmenting customers into different groups based on their purchasing behavior and demographics. It uses clustering algorithms like K-means and hierarchical clustering to identify distinct customer segments.



Apr 1, 2024













Visualizing Global CO2 Emissions



R

Data Visualization

Environmental Science



This project involves creating visualizations to show trends in global CO2 emissions over time. It includes data extraction from public databases, data cleaning, and using visualization libraries to create interactive charts and graphs.



Jul 1, 2024

Supported monthly reporting and contributed to client presentations by providing data-driven insights and performance trends.
Analyzed the impact of time-related factors (e.g., time of day, day of week) on customer shopping behavior to inform strategic recommendations.
Conducted competitor analysis to benchmark performance and identify growth opportunities for clients.

Lessons learned, resources used, and lots of gratitude.

title: index
text:
for this blog post, i want to talk about all the data analytics ecosystem that currently works for me. the motivation for this is that, before this my work feels like everywhere, and it makes me feel somehow not conducive to work on my projects just because of how messy everything is. but after learning here, i think i now have a more seamless workflow which make project works a lot easier, and it is easier to pick up where i left off. some of these stuff that have been so important for me now are 1) quarto 2) github 3) R - building function and packages
some other tips and tricks that make my workflow better
what i feel is missing now: 1) collaboration on projects especially with people not familiar with these tools 2) learn how to work with version control better 3) communication

title: I Finally Have a Website (Built with Quarto!)
text:
Overcomplicating My Website (Then Got It Done with Quarto)
Finally, I have a working website! This has been a Hacky Hour project of mine throughout the semester. It seems easy at first‚Äîbut I got a bit ambitious. I thought, ‚ÄúI want to design it exactly the way I want to,‚Äù and went down a whole rabbit hole‚Ä¶ only to realise, I‚Äôm not a web developer.
While I definitely learned a lot along the way, what I needed for my website could‚Äôve been done way more easily using the templates that already exist. I wish I had known that earlier. The first few weeks were basically me messing around, trying to get Claude to design a beautiful layout for me.
Eventually, I just gave in (gratefully) and settled on the ready-made Quarto website template.
Big shoutout to the NUMBAT team, particularly the HACKY HOUR group
This whole thing wouldn‚Äôt have been possible without the help from the NUMBAT team at Monash. I‚Äôm incredibly new to all this, and they‚Äôve been so generous‚Äîhelping me with all the little things I needed to get this site functioning. It would‚Äôve been so much harder (and way more time-consuming) without them.
Still a bit bare, but it‚Äôs a start






Homepage







CV-html









CV-pdf





Right now, the website still looks pretty empty, but I‚Äôll be filling it up over time. Most of my energy so far has gone into building the CV page. Even just wrapping my head around how a Quarto website works took up a surprising amount of time. What really helped, though, was the amazing community of people who‚Äôve put in the effort to make this process more beginner-friendly.
Here are a few of the resources I used (aside from the wonderful humans from Hacky Hour):

Posit PBC on Youtube ‚Äì Their videos on building personal websites with Quarto were my main reference point and helped me get started.
The Quarto GitHub repository ‚Äì It was super useful to see how they built their own website.
Publishing both HTML and PDF with Quarto by Cynthia Huang ‚Äì This was a game changer for building my CV page. It showed me how to create a clean HTML page and render a PDF version alongside it.

Feeling excited (and just slightly overwhelmed)
Now that the site is up, I suddenly feel like there‚Äôs so much I can do with it‚Äîso many ideas I could add, projects to showcase, things to try out. It‚Äôs exciting! Of course, time and energy are limited, so we‚Äôll see how much I can actually get done‚Ä¶ but I‚Äôm hopeful.
If you‚Äôre thinking of building your own site: go for it. Keep it simple. Don‚Äôt overthink it (like I did). Use the templates. Ask for help. It really does get better the more you chip away at it.
And just like that‚Ä¶ I think this is my first blog post on the site. Wild.

title: Leong Zhuan Kee, Vis
text:
I‚Äôm a PhD student in the Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics at Monash University. My research looks at multidrug-resistant organisms, using data to explore issues related to intensive care and hospital settings.
What drew me to this area is the reminder that behind every data point is a real person‚Äîsomeone who was seriously unwell. That perspective keeps me grounded and gives purpose to the work I do.
I‚Äôm especially interested in healthcare analytics, population health, and statistical and mathematical modeling‚Äîand I‚Äôm hoping to grow further in these areas. On the side, I‚Äôve also been working on tools to make data cleaning more efficient, especially for messy datasets with entry errors.
